4. .......... d6 - standard moves of the Sicilian Defence.  I now play Nc3 to develop a piece and support my e pawn.  I think this game will transpose into a kind of Naijdorf.

8. .......... 0-0 - both players have developed most of their pieces and have castled on opposite sides - this can involve a race against time in mating attacks and pawn storms but it doesn't quite happen here.
12. e5 - I hope to win a pawn here but things do not work out quite as I expect.

15. ......... Qb6 - after a plethora of exchanges black eschews taking the pawn on d6 and tries a mating attack on the queenside.  Black is threatening a nasty knight fork on c3 as the b2 pawn is pinned so I get out of the pin by playing my king to a1.  Now comes a black pawn storm which fortunately for me does not go much further.

17. Bd3 - I now complete my development with this multi-purpose move.  Firstly it connects my two rooks.  Frere Leblanc defends the c2 pawn and is lined up on the h7 square which will become the focal point for a match turning combo later on.
20. g3 - I decide to back up my f4 pawn - the d6 pawn is a gonner but it is poisoned!  You will see how after black's next move.
21. c4!! - After this move the knight must move allowing a discovered attack.

22. Bh7  - here it is - a discovered attack.  This is different to a discovered check because the piece which is in line with the discovery is not the king.  The king is in check though and black must deal with that.  Her best move is to take Frere Leblanc which she does but this allows me to take the rook on d6 as d6 is only defended by the Wicked Witch of the West whereas Glenda and one of my rooks is trained on that square.  So black now drops the exchange.

24. ........ Qc5 - black does not wish to trade queens as if you are down in material you need to trade pawns rather than pieces - also it will snuff out any counterplay that black will have.  I think that Qe4 may have been stronger than the text move here though as it gangs up on c2.
27. ............ Rxc4 - I decided to hand back a pawn for the exchange to get the queens off.  With my next move I regain the pawn and once again emerge a clear exchange up.
31. Kb1 - not 31. Ra5?? - this allows Nb3 forking king and rook.
33. Rb4 - I am prepared to double my queenside pawns to get the rooks off.  I will still be able to pick off the black a pawn and support one of my queenside pawns through to crown.
34. Rxa4 - here I was wondering whether it was better to back up my h pawn.  However after black's 35th move it turned out to be the right decision.
35. ........ Nd2 ?? - black cannot resist giving this check.  Nc5 would have complicated things but I think white was still winning there.

36. Kc1!! - the winner - even Henry comes to the party.  The black knight will be trapped.  Black's best move which avoids immediate material loss is Nf3 and after Rb3 Rf2 but then I will play a4 and how can black preserve her knight and stop Glenda from making an appearance on a8?

An Open Sicilian position via transposition but with colors reversed. The move 5...Qxd5 can be seen in Fischer-Tukmakov Buenos Aires 1970 and in a small handful of games here on Gameknot.

The Gameknot database has two common paths from here: 7.d3 0-0 8.Nf3 and 7.Qc2 0-0 8.Nf3. When comparing the Gameknot and World databases it is hard to determine which path is better. Whether or not the Queen is better on c2 or another square is something I haven't determined yet.
White has constructed a Hedgehog-like pawn wall on the third row.
Interesting to consider would be 8..Qf6. It appears twice in the databases; one draw (World) and one win for Black (Gameknot).
The more common move is Nf3 and I'm not certain why I held off on playing it in favor of Nd2.

Not knowing what to play as Black I decide to go with the Sicilian.
Having read the Wikipedia article on Sicilians I figured I liked the Kalashnikov Sicilian the best and took it out for a spin.
White threatens 6.Nd6  Bxd6 7.Qxd6. The Old Lowenthal Sicilian allows this but the Kalashnikov has a different way of dealing with it.
Protected by Black's Queen and Bishop the threat of Nd6  has been deflected.

Most common moves for White in this position are 6.c4 preventing a later b5 by Black or 6.Nc3 taking immediate aim at the hole created on d5. This particular Sicilian variation allows this hole in exchange for more active piece play.

Development move choices were Nf6 Be6/d7 and Be7. The move 7...Nf6 threatening the e4 pawn was probably the better choice as it would have discouraged an immediate 8.Nd5 by White. ***** (Edit for Wakefield - 7...b5 is indeed more thematic and I miscalculated the value of playing it a turn earlier then I did. I was perhaps overly concerned about 8.Nd5 or a wierd piece sac on b5 since White attacked the square 3 times.

Had c4 been played earlier White could have played Nc2 into the pocket behind the c3 Knight. However this would have left d4 unguarded by a pawn possibly allowing Black to park his own Knight there if given the chance.

The open d-file and the placement of the Knights are White's compensation for the earlier loss of tempo from the Knight on Ne3 which has had to move 6 times in the last 9 moves.

Black must attempt to use his lead in tempo and space and translate it into a developmental or positional advantage before White finishes his own development and takes advantage of the d5 hole by parking a Knight on it.
Best square for the light Bishop though it blocks the use of the d-file for the Queen. The triple coverage of the hole prevents Black from playing d5 for the time being.
Covering the hole again so that an exchange will leave a White pawn on d5 plugging up the hole which would be favorable to Black.

I notice that with White's c1 Bishop still on its original square if I allow White to take on b5 and then take back with the a6 pawn White will be forced to deal with the hanging Rook on a1. The c1 Bishop is in an awkward position pinned in as it is. The move a4 may have been premature.
I leave the a4 pawn alone and step my Knight forward in an attempt to get the Bishop pair.

Black plays a 'zwischen' move before taking back on b5. The first book I ever read on chess was Weapons of Chess by Bruce Pandolfini. The zwischen or inbetween move and other tactical concepts I learned from that book played a large part in shaping my early chess.

Had White played Bd2 earlier he would have been forced to recapture with the pawn creating an isolated b-pawn.
The better choice rather then allow an isolated b-pawn.
I take back revealing the attack on the a1 Rook.
The b5 pawn is undefended but I now attack the e4 pawn with my f6 Knight and with the Queen along the h1-a8 diagonal.
To facilitate the taking of Black's b5 pawn White guards the e4 pawn a third time.

I plan to move Ba6 for a pin or skewer along the a6-f1 diagonal in anticipation of the capture of my b5 pawn which I can't defend. It is my hope that either the pin or skewer will help me win material and so this may be analogous to a "Poisoned Pawn".

I had expected 17.Nxb5 instead. It is possible that White wanted his Knights to remain where they were to take advantage of the d5 hole and/or to more easily prevent d5. I am not sure whether or not this constitutes as a blunder.

I skewer the Queen and the Rook behind it. I will get one or the other in exchange for my Bishop which is worth the sacrifice of one of my last Queen side pawns as long as I can eliminate White's majority on that side later.
Still covering d5 with the Queen.
I have considered a plan at this point on how to trade down for an advantage. I attack White's Queen one more time to see where he will put it.
Still covering the d5 square. However with White's Queen now on the a-file I feel I can move ahead with my idea.

I really appreciate the Bishop's Pair when I have it and though the idea of raking bishops along the a6-f1 and a7-g1 diagonals appealed to me I knew that trading down would be better in the long run if I was to get material back for my pawn.

I had only considered Nxf1 but Kxf1 makes much more sense bringing the King closer to the middle in anticipation of the approaching Endgame. White still controls d5 4 times so I have my work cut out for me.
I begin by exchanging Queens. This takes advantage of the double duty on the c3 Knight and draws it away from protecting d5 further reducing White's control of that square.
I now play d5 and sacrifice my last Queen side pawn to gain time to move my Bishop before White's King gets any closer to his pieces.
White accepts my pawn offering clearing the way for Bc5.

The c1 Bishop which still hasn't moved this game is currently doing two jobs at once. I intend to overload that Bishop by exchanging off the e3 Knight and picking up the pawn back on b2 with my Rook. Playing the sacrifice of d5 was necessary because if I had I taken more time to get to the a7-g1 diagonal with my Bishop the opportunity would have passed as White's King would be sitting on e2 or f2.

To prevent Black from sniping off the d5 pawn after the exchange on e3 White throws up his c-pawn. 23.Nc3 was another possibility but after the exchange on e3 there would have been no way to save the c-pawn now stuck behind the Knight after 24...Rxb2.
Threatening the Knight. Had 23.Nc3 been played Black would have been able to pickup a second pawn the next move on c2.
Threatening both minor pieces at once.
Which is easily enough defended against.
With two passed pawns on the Queen side Black begins moving his King over.
White wishes to deny d6 to my King and creates a miniature pawn wall.

I move in front of the pawns and begin planning my next moves. I've noticed that if White moves Ke3 or Kd3 he will self-pin the Knight to his King. It becomes my plan to take on d5 the moment this happens.

I must confess that while this move looks brilliant on the surface it is in fact a blunder that went unpunished... While I had counted on Kc4 and had worked out how to eliminate White's Bishop by sacrificing my Knight and a pawn for it I had not counted on Kc2 which would have left me with two undefended pieces that were simultaneously threatened. I could do one of three things:

1). Go for a Rook vs Bishop and Knight endgame where I had 4 pawns to White's 3 after a sequence like 30.Kc2 Rb4 31.Nxd5 Rc4  32.Kd3 Rxc5 

2). I could trade away all the pieces with 30.Kc2 Rxc3 31.Bxc3 Nxc3 32.Kxc3 Kc6 and settle for blockading the c5 pawn with my King with only a slight positional advantage of an extra King side pawn or 

3). I could go for a Knight vs Bishop endgame with equal amounts of pawns using the sequence 30.Kc2 Rxc3 31.Bxc3 Kc6 and then followed by Kxc6 the next move. Of the three the largest chances of a draw would come from this one.

None of these really appealed to me though. Would 29...Nxd5 30.Kc2 have cost me the game? Maybe maybe not. But Kc2 would have equalized for White in most of the scenarios I envisioned and I would have thrown away my two point advantage I had worked so hard for. As the old saying goes Once you find a good move find a better one.

The lure of protecting c5 and getting the fork must have been fairly appealing and so White passes over 30.Kc2 and goes for 30.Kc4. The move 29...Nxd5 was perhaps my weakest move in the entire game and is the one move I am most dissatisfied with despite how it cleverly exploited the self-pinning of the c3 Knight.
Sacrificing the Knight to save the Rook and setting up Rd4  to win the Bishop. White optionally could have played Kd3 but it would likely have meant forsaking the c5 pawn.
White goes for the Knight setting up Rd4 .
Interestingly if the f-pawn had been on f6 instead of its original square this would have been checkmate. Opportunity lost I suppose.
Only move stepping away from c5.
Between White's two remaining minor pieces I wanted to eliminate the Bishop the most and so this combination came in handy.
A good move saving the g-pawn so that the remaining White King side pawns will be linked rather then isolated.
I threaten the Knight and the f3 pawn. I knew that Ne4 would eventually be played and had seen the possibility of the Ng5 fork but had worked out that Rxf3 would still be safe.
Protecting the c5 pawn and moving towards the protection of the King.
I take the f3 pawn
White goes for the fork and ...
gets 'forked' by the f6 pawn. Its more of an intermezzo then a true fork since White can still save the Knight.
Of the three available King moves only this one saves the Knight.
I move away and threaten the c5 pawn. With White's King now sitting on e4 the Knight can not return in time to guard the pawn which would force Kd4 to save it.
Rather then get cut off from the remaining pawns White leaves his King where it is and takes on h7. This pawn was bait and is part of a trap I had worked out to eliminate White's last minor piece.

I have now successfully corralled the Knight with two pawns and my King. At the earliest possible moment I will swing over with Rh3 to capture it. White's c-pawn is three squares away from promotion but Rh3 Rxh7 and Rh8 allow me to cover the promotion square before it arrives.

Three pawns for a Knight is fairly reasonable.

I match White's King movement with my own. By forcing White to walk in front of his pawn I give my Rook time to capture on h2 and swing over to the c-file.
Moving Kd8 is unnecessary as there is enough time to capture and then intercept the c-pawn by the time it reaches c7.

Pretty standard development from here. White protects its pawns black moves to attack whites knights because the game from here looks to be closed. I.E. strategy is to attack the opponents closed pieces with your open pieces to create an imbalance between your pieces that are stronger when closed and his pieces which are stronger when open.

The line that usually follows is 7. Nc3..e6. Which gives the d knight a post and makes it harder for white to open up the center of the board when black decides to trade his bishop for a knight forcing the imbalance.

Instead Black trades knights on c3. Which is disastrous. Not only has he given up the center of the board but he is undeveloped and Whites pawn structure(that cascade thing which i can't remember the name of) makes his white bishop even stronger.

Blacks white bishop is already constrained and is about to be constrained even farther. As handy as it is to develop the other bishop Black is developing this bishop into a position it can make little use of. It only has one square it can move into. Despite the black cascade whites black bishop has many more options and a much larger sphere of influence

The game which should have been about black hammering home a post on d5 is now about White owning the queen side of the board.
